content.description:
Climb up a weakness to a V shaped mini roof- multiple options here, but the basic concept is you're setting yourself up for a hard face boulder that has multiple solutions depending on your height and style.

Clip the 5th bolt mid boulder, or skip it and don't fall!



Look for a left leaning weakness into a right facing crack. "V" mini roof at the 3rd bolt. 

5 bolts, rap rings

Approach via "Bailey's", passing the anchor and clipping the first bolt on the extension overhead, then have yourself a lean into the corner for a no hands rest where you can think about your life choices. 

When you're ready, cruise up through a bit of easy ground to gain the roof clip. All that's left is a very short boulder that could be nominated for things such as "most imaginary undercling", "most unreasonable haymaker", "drop knee of the millennium", full "gorilla trying to tear apart a car tire", or maybe just "nope, dirt".

One last clip, one last big move, and then it's yours to botch!



Extension on Bailey's

9 bolts total, rap rings

Very important, if there are not buckets that you can reach from the ground, you're on the wrong ramp!

Start on big holds to gain your first bolt on the ramp. From then on, follow the cruisey ramp/corner that links with "The Meat Show" to a shared anchor.



There are 3 left leaning ramps towards on Kiss the Sky Wall. The left most is Kiss the Sky, the right most is this, Cue the Masses. The bottom is where the grass starts on the belay ledge. 

7 bolts, rap rings

Basically climb the pseudo-shared start with "Summer Rain" to the base of the crack/corner. Here, break left onto the face where the climbing immediately ramps up. Wide compression and tenuous lay-backing brings you through a cryptic, and slightly challenging first crux (maybe 5.12b) to a good rest. 

Next, break up and left for more lay-backing and wide compression - this time much less secure, much pumpier, even higher feet, and slightly imaginary holds (5.12d). Race the pump to the thank-God crimps just over the bulge. 

Plot twist, you made it to the crimps and you're flamed. Race the pump through one more bolt to bolt sequence of easily duffable climbing to actual rest-sized holds. After this, cruise an easy weakness to one final steep section (moderate). 



Squeezed in between "Summer Rain" and "Kazathon". Look for the bolt line that pulls onto the face just left of the right-facing corner/crack (~4th bolt). 

13 bolts, drop in anchor

A complete bucket slam for 3 bolts, then the trouble starts. Why is there chalk where there is no hold? You'll find out-

2 cruxes with several spots for rests in between. Hard where it's thin and vertical to slightly overhanging; delicate footwork required!



From the bridge head slightly right up the ramp/ledge. The belay stance is just at the start of where the ramp is smooth and the creek boulders stop. The climb goes up a series of left leaning cracks/weaknesses down low.

10 bolts, rap rings

Cruise a sustained 5.11 ramp to a high boulder shared with "Purple Hazing". Incredible stemming, delicate slab and corner climbing, and an even more delicate, airy boulder. 

8-10" draw on the last bolt to keep your rope clear of the rock. 8-10" draw on the left anchor bolt if you want to clip from below!



The prominent (biggest) left, left leaning ramp.

7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Do not fear the high first bolt, climb big holds in the very secure corner to clip. 

Leave the corner and traverse right on a rail. Straight forward, gymnastic climbing on good holds brings you through the overhang (the crux is when the good holds are far apart...).  good rest can be found as the angle eases - traverse right from the nearly no hands stem/jug rest before heading up. 

The bolt line merges with "Cue the Masses" and shares an anchor. 



Peels right out of the "Kiss the Sky" (biggest, left) ramp.

6 bolts, rap rings

Cover 3 bolts of easy terrain to gain underclings just right of a fin feature. Pull onto the fin and boulder to surmount the overhang - crimps, heels and pinches, desperate - and gain a rest on the slab. 

You've cleared the crux, but the route is not over! Trend up and left across the slab using a key blind foot. At the top of the slab, traverse left and head up the right facing corner. As the rock transitions to dark grey, step right onto the "head wall" and clip the anchors. 



Walk towards the right end of Kiss the Sky wall. This route starts just right of the "Cue the Masses" ramp from the grass. Starts off of a big flat hold that you stand on to clip the first bolt. 

9 bolts, quick links (they will twist your rope horrendously)

Stick clip and jump off the platform on bad holds to keep your shoes dry. Easy climbing brings you through the first 3 bolts (stay right of the bolt line at the 3rd bolt) to a stem rest. Chalk up and bust left; small holds on the overhang quickly drain your forearms! A committing move to a jug gets you through the crux. 

All that's left is victory climbing to the chains! Very droppable victory climbing... After the jug rest head up through the overhang on big holds until you can cross the arete to the right (at the bolt, clip it after you've crossed the arete) and gain a good rest. Finish out on the pumpy top crux of Kazathon (consider skipping the last bolt - just above the top bulge - if you're flamed). 



First bolt line right of the platform. Look for a brief, right facing corner around the 3rd bolt, and a seam a few feet to the right of the corner. 

9 bolts, rap rings

climbs.name: Pirate
climbs.fa: Sean Elliott, Greg Tos, Lloyd King, 2003

content.description:
Climb the easy face/crack/corner shared with "Schooner" until the roof. Clip a bolt out to the right (bolt 3) and pull up and over the roof to the right, using a micro-tufa to gain a nearly no-hands rest. A few moves of approach climbing guards an unlikely, tight stem-box/gaston boulder. Pull the boulder to gain buckets and then trend back left to merge with and finish on "Schooner". 



Start off the platform on the far left of Kiss the Sky Wall, split right after the 2nd bolt

10 bolts, fixed anchor

A Jasper classic for the grade. No bolt to bolt sequence harder than 12c, sustained, airy, beautiful.

Easy and entertaining climbing leads you to the base of a very clean, vertical face. Sustained, thin face climbing brings you to a decent rest just below a roof. Traverse right following the bolt line through the first boulder, clip, and then dive straight into an elegant and airy final boulder. 

Easy climbing to the anchor...if you can reach it!

Quickdraw beta:
Long draw (double draw length) the two bolts below the roof and use a 8-10" dog-bone draw on the bolt just after the first boulder to keep your rope from pinching on the rock. 

Leave a 8-10" draw on the left anchor bolt so you can reach it from below.



Identify the prominent left, left leaning ramp in the middle of the Kiss the Sky wall. This is "Kiss the Sky" which shares the second boulder with "Purple Hazing". Look for the bolt line that comes in from the left to link up with this ramp. 

10 bolts, rap rings

An incredibly aesthetic line following a layback/undercling crack into face climbing. Long, lots of climbing at or near the grade, and a sit down rest if you want it!

The feet are difficult to see, but there are lots. Brief sun in the afternoon, and almost surely a wet rope if there are no draws to guide it down. 



Look for the left facing corner crack to roof crack feature- just to your left after you cross the bridge. Belay from the platform. 

9 bolts, steel biner on the chains

Approach via "Summer Rain" (5.10c), throwing a draw on the anchor chains and continuing up. Once you hit your first bolt on the extension, reach back and undo your draw on the Summer Rain chains. 

Pull through the roof using more elegance than strength to a no hands rest. Finish out on easier face climbing that will be harder than you expect!



Look for the "Summer Rain" finger crack/dihedral, this is the extension. 

11 bolts, rap rings

One of the most slamming 10s in the park! Cruise a finger/tips crack at the back of a dihedral/open book feature. Finish at the chains just below the roof.



Look for the finger crack/open book feature, a few meters before the detached boulder on the belay ramp/ledge.

5 bolts, steel biner

Nothing makes you feel like a 5.12 climber like cruising the super fun first 6 bolts of this line. Dihedral, face, slab, buckets, stemming, so much fun!

And then nothing makes you feel like you don't climb 5.12 like the part where the holds stop. Solve a cryptic bolder to regain big holds and clip the chains!



Look for the left most left leaning ramp on Kiss the Sky Wall, this climb crosses the ramp at ~1/3 height. 2 bolts up to a mini roof, then traverse right under the roof to tag bolt 3 at the right edge of the roof that meets with the ramp. This is your line!

7 bolts, steel biner

Approach via "To Infinity" taking your time to have a chill on the anchor clipping holds. When you're good and ready, climb to the lone bolt on the extension through easy (5.11) to clip off a blind finger bucket. 

Enter the boulder-
Left: refrigerator on terrible holds with a couple of big throws
Right: a difficult cross to set up for an even more difficult throw to terrible crimps or a slightly less terrible pinch.

At least there's a clipping "bucket"! 



Identify the left most left leaning ramp in the middle of Kiss the Sky Wall. Look for the anchors directly above the middle of the ramp at the top of the wall. The bolt line crosses the ramp at ~1/3 height.

9 bolts (1 for the "To Infinity" anchor), rap rings

The hardest wall in Jasper hosting several 5.12s and a few 5.13s, as well as some stellar .10s and .11s! SSE aspect- sun until late afternoon.  
  
 Logistically challenging on some lines to pull your rope and keep it dry.
